pageProps.body:
Sequences

Sequences are denoted in the forms

x1,x2,…,xn,xn,and xnn=1∞.{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n}\text, \\ {x_n}\text, \\ \text{and }{x_n}_{n=1}^{\infty}\text.x1​,x2​,…,xn​,xn​,and xn​n=1∞​.

Limit of a sequence

If the terms of a sequence xn{x_n}xn​ approach a unique number LLL as nnn increases (if ana_nan​ can be made arbitrarily close to LLL), then the limit lim⁡n→∞xn\lim_{n\to\infty} x_nlimn→∞​xn​ converges to LLL. If the terms do not approach a single number as nnn increases, the sequence has no limit, and it diverges.

A converging sequence approaching 000.

A diverging sequence (approaching nothing).

Infinite series

From Infinite Series
Go to text →

An infinite series can be viewed as a sum of an infinite set of numbers, with the form

x1+x2+⋯+xn+⋯.x_1+x_2+\cdots+x_n+\cdots\text.x1​+x2​+⋯+xn​+⋯.

For instance, the infinite series

S12+14+18+⋯+12n=2n−12nS_\frac12+\frac14+\frac18+\cdots+\frac{1}{2^n}=\frac{2^n-1}{2^n}S21​​+41​+81​+⋯+2n1​=2n2n−1​

approaches 111 as nnn approaches ∞\infty∞.

lim⁡n→∞Sn=1\lim_{n\to\infty}{S_n}=1n→∞lim​Sn​=1

Sequence of partial sums

From Sequence of Partial Sums
Go to text →

The sequence of partial sums of a sequence Sn{S_n}Sn​ is defined as

S1,S2,…,Sn,{S_1, S_2, \ldots, S_n}\text,S1​,S2​,…,Sn​,

where

Sn=x1+x2+⋯+xn.S_n=x_1+x_2+\cdots+x_n\text.Sn​=x1​+x2​+⋯+xn​.

This can be used to evaluate the (infinite) series

∑k=1∞xk\sum_{k=1}^\infty{x_k}k=1∑∞​xk​

with the limit

lim⁡k→∞xk=∑k=1∞xk.\lim_{k\to\infty}{x_k}=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}{x_k}\text.k→∞lim​xk​=k=1∑∞​xk​.
